qas.question: What is the name of the rule that protects the landowner if their conservation efforts fall short?
Why is this particular rule so controversial?

answers.text: the Fish and Wildlife Service (FWS) loses much ability to further protect a species if the mitigation measures by the landowner prove insufficient.

qas.question: If the landowner fails to adequately protect the species, what penalties do they face with the "No Surprises" rule?

answers.text: The landowner or permittee would not be required to set aside additional land or pay more in conservation money

qas.question: Who covers the cost of additional efforts if the ITP holder's efforts fall short?

answers.text: The federal government would have to pay for additional protection measures

plausible_answers.text: the Fish and Wildlife Service (FWS) loses much ability to further protect a species

qas.question: What policy protects the species from unforeseen circumstances?
What is granted after the No Surprises rule comes into play?
What is the federal government is not required to pay for?

plausible_answers.text: additional land or pay more in conservation money

qas.question: What does the No Surprises rule requires landowners to put aside?

context: <a0_0><b5_0>The "No Surprises" rule<b5_0/><a0_0/> is meant to protect the landowner if "unforeseen circumstances" occur which make the landowner's efforts to prevent or mitigate harm to the species fall short. The "No Surprises" policy may be the most controversial of the recent reforms of the law, because once an <b6_0>Incidental Take Permit<b6_0/> is granted, <a1_0><b4_0>the Fish and Wildlife Service (FWS) loses much ability to further protect a species<b4_0/> if the mitigation measures by the landowner prove insufficient.<a1_0/> <a2_0>The landowner or permittee would not be required to set aside <b8_0>additional land or pay more in conservation money<b8_0/><a2_0/>. <a3_0>The federal government would have to pay for <b7_0>additional protection measures<b7_0/><a3_0/>.
